title: R44316
content: Widespread drought in the West, particularly in states like California, Oregon, Nevada, Washington, Montana, and Idaho, has led to extreme conditions. Congressional interest in managing water resources during drought has increased due to the impact on agriculture, communities, industry, recreation, and the environment. Federal government historically invested in water supply development, but defers to state and local governments for allocation. Federal efforts to address drought and water supply impacts have been limited due to deferring to state and local governments for allocation. Legislative proposals focus on managing water projects, supporting drought-related programs, and mitigating effects on agriculture, water supplies, and the environment. Bills introduced in Congress include S. 176, S. 1837, S. 1894, H.R. 2898, H.R. 2983, and H.R. 3045. H.R. 2898, the Western Water and American Food Security Act, passed the House on July 17, 2015. Negotiations are ongoing in the House and Senate to address concerns by federal and state governments regarding water resource management. A draft House bill was discussed during the FY2016 Omnibus, but no bill was introduced. Similarly, a new Senate bill addressing outstanding issues has not been introduced yet. New language is expected in the second session of the 114th Congress. Key provisions in H.R. 2898 and S. 1894 are being analyzed, including specific provisions for California and broader implications for nationwide water resources financing. The report discusses key provisions in H.R. 2898 and S. 1894 related to water resource management, including financing, permitting issues, project repayment policies, and support for new water storage and reuse. It does not cover every detail in the bills but refers to other CRS products for more comprehensive analysis. Stakeholders have shown both support and opposition, with questions raised about their implementation. The bills direct water managers to maximize water supplies for users while adhering to laws and regulations. Some controversy surrounds how bills address implementation of the federal Endangered Species Act, specifically regarding water management under federal biological opinions designed to protect Delta smelt and salmon populations.
